Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 1, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
In the celestial court of the Jade Emperor
lived seven princesses. Each had their chosen place in court, but the youngest princess
had a special skill. She could pluck clouds from the sky
and spin them into the softest robes. Her work was so precise, not even the most expert eye
could find a seam. But her craft was the same day after day,
and she longed for new inspiration. Finally, the Queen Mother granted 
the weaver permission to visit Earth. The other princesses would accompany her to protect their sister 
from earthly dangers. Dressed in special robes that allowed them
to fly between Heaven and Earth, the sisters soared down from the sky. The weaver was in awe 
of the rolling hills and rivers, and the sisters decided to swim
in one of the glittering streams. As the weaver floated,
she dreamt about staying forever. Meanwhile, a lone cowherd
approached the riverbank. He came here often
to sweep his parent’s grave and speak with his only companion— a stoic bull who listened patiently 
to the cowherd’s sorrows. But upon seeing the weaver’s beauty,
the cowherd forgot his routine. While he longed to introduce himself,
his lonely lifestyle had made him timid. Thankfully, the bull saw his friend's
plight and offered some advice. He told the cowherd of the swimmer’s 
celestial origins and of her dream to stay on Earth; but also that she could only remain 
if she lost her ticket back to Heaven. As the cowherd approached,
the princesses flew away in fear— leaving their dreaming sister behind. While keeping her magic robes hidden, the cowherd offered his own garment 
as a substitute. And after gaining her trust, 
the pair began exploring the countryside. She was struck by his caring nature, and he learned to see 
the world’s wonder through her eyes. Before long, the two had
fallen deeply in love. The weaver and the cowherd
built a prosperous life. Their farm flourished, and the weaver 
taught her skills to local villagers. As time marched on, the pair was 
blessed with two healthy children, but their bull was growing old. Before he died, the bull implored
the family to keep his hide and use its magic at their time of need. While the husband grieved for his friend, the weaver’s mind turned
to her other family. Dusting off her magical robe,
she decided to pay a visit to the heavens. But when the weaver
swept into her old home, no one seemed surprised to see her. With a start, she realized
that barely any time had passed— for a year on Earth
was merely a day in Heaven. When her family learned of her new life,
they were enraged. How dare she waste her love on a human? The weaver tried to escape back to Earth, but the Queen Mother plucked 
a golden hairpin from her head and tore through the sky. A great gulf opened, forming a river
of stars between Heaven and Earth. Below, the cowherd trembled, but he also
remembered the bull’s final words. Hastily placing each child in a basket, he draped the bull’s pelt
over his back and hurtled upwards. Above the clouds, each lover attempted
to wade through the surging stars. But no matter how hard they struggled, the gulf between them
only grew wider. Day after day, the Queen Mother
watched without pity. Years passed, and the weaver 
and the cowherd had no one, except the passing magpies 
to cheer them on. Finally, their love moved
the Queen Mother’s heart. While she couldn’t forgive
her granddaughter entirely, the Queen Mother would allow the weaver
to meet her earthly family once a year. And so, in late summer, the magpies
form a bridge across the Milky Way, reuniting the weaver and the cowherd. At this time of year, millions of people
in East and Southeast Asian countries tell similar tales of these 
star-crossed lovers, celebrating their annual reunion.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: The weaver was skilled at making ____ out of _____.
Options: A. Ropes; light, B. Baskets; bamboo, C. Shirts; silk, D. Robes; clouds
Correct Option: D

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What was the special skill of the youngest princess in the celestial court of the Jade Emperor? Options: A. She could weave the most beautiful tapestries., B. She could pluck clouds from the sky and spin them into the softest robes., C. She could sing the most enchanting songs., D. She could create the most exquisite paintings. Correct Option: B
Question 2: Why did the weaver long for new inspiration in her craft? Options: A. She was tired of working with the same materials every day., B. She wanted to learn new techniques from the other princesses., C. Her work was the same day after day, and she yearned for something more., D. She was dissatisfied with the quality of her work. Correct Option: C
Question 3: What was the Queen Mother's condition for allowing the weaver to visit Earth? Options: A. She had to bring back a gift from Earth., B. She had to complete a task given by the Queen Mother., C. She had to promise to return to Heaven after a year., D. She had to meet the Queen Mother's expectations of her work. Correct Option: C
Question 4: What advice did the bull give to the cowherd about the weaver? Options: A. He told the cowherd to ignore the weaver and focus on his own life., B. He told the cowherd to be cautious around the weaver because she was from Heaven., C. He told the cowherd that the weaver could only remain on Earth if she lost her ticket back to Heaven., D. He told the cowherd to try to win the weaver's heart. Correct Option: C
Question 5: What was the consequence of the weaver's decision to stay on Earth? Options: A. She was able to return to Heaven and resume her life as a princess., B. She was able to live a happy life with the cowherd and their children., C. A great gulf opened between Heaven and Earth, making it difficult for her to return home., D. She was punished by the Queen Mother for disobeying her. Correct Option: C
Question 6: What did the bull ask the family to do with his hide before he died? Options: A. He asked them to bury him with it., B. He asked them to use its magic at their time of need., C. He asked them to give it to the weaver as a gift., D. He asked them to keep it as a reminder of their love. Correct Option: B
Question 7: What happened when the weaver returned to Heaven after being away for a year on Earth? Options: A. She was greeted as a hero by her family and friends., B. She was met with surprise by her family, who barely noticed her absence., C. She was punished by the Queen Mother for her disobedience., D. She was able to return to her life as a princess without any consequences. Correct Option: B
Question 8: What was the result of the weaver and the cowherd's love for each other? Options: A. The Queen Mother was moved to forgive the weaver and allow her to return to Earth., B. The weaver was able to live a happy life with the cowherd and their children, but only once a year., C. The weaver and the cowherd were able to be together in Heaven, but their love was not strong enough to overcome the gulf between them., D. The weaver and the cowherd were separated forever, and their love was forgotten. Correct Option: B
Question 9: What is the significance of the magpies forming a bridge across the Milky Way? Options: A. It is a sign of good luck and prosperity for the weaver and the cowherd., B. It is a reminder of the weaver's love for the cowher family in Heaven., C. It is a way for the weaver and the cowherd to be reunited once a year., D. It is a symbol of the Queen Mother's forgiveness and love for the weaver. Correct Option: C
Question 10: Why do millions of people in East and Southeast Asian countries tell similar tales of the weaver and the cowherd? Options: A. Because they believe in the power of true love to overcome any obstacle., B. Because they want to honor the weaver's bravery and determination., C. Because they celebrate the annual reunion of the weaver and the cowherd., D. Because they believe in the magic of the bull's hide. Correct Option: C


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 1. 

Although the question wording is different, the intent and content of Question 1 are similar to the ground truth MCQ. The correct option in Question 1 (B. She could pluck clouds from the sky and spin them into the softest robes.) is also similar to the correct option in the ground truth MCQ (D. Robes; clouds). 

Index of the most similar generated MCQ: 1.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 1, Question 2
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
In the celestial court of the Jade Emperor
lived seven princesses. Each had their chosen place in court, but the youngest princess
had a special skill. She could pluck clouds from the sky
and spin them into the softest robes. Her work was so precise, not even the most expert eye
could find a seam. But her craft was the same day after day,
and she longed for new inspiration. Finally, the Queen Mother granted 
the weaver permission to visit Earth. The other princesses would accompany her to protect their sister 
from earthly dangers. Dressed in special robes that allowed them
to fly between Heaven and Earth, the sisters soared down from the sky. The weaver was in awe 
of the rolling hills and rivers, and the sisters decided to swim
in one of the glittering streams. As the weaver floated,
she dreamt about staying forever. Meanwhile, a lone cowherd
approached the riverbank. He came here often
to sweep his parent’s grave and speak with his only companion— a stoic bull who listened patiently 
to the cowherd’s sorrows. But upon seeing the weaver’s beauty,
the cowherd forgot his routine. While he longed to introduce himself,
his lonely lifestyle had made him timid. Thankfully, the bull saw his friend's
plight and offered some advice. He told the cowherd of the swimmer’s 
celestial origins and of her dream to stay on Earth; but also that she could only remain 
if she lost her ticket back to Heaven. As the cowherd approached,
the princesses flew away in fear— leaving their dreaming sister behind. While keeping her magic robes hidden, the cowherd offered his own garment 
as a substitute. And after gaining her trust, 
the pair began exploring the countryside. She was struck by his caring nature, and he learned to see 
the world’s wonder through her eyes. Before long, the two had
fallen deeply in love. The weaver and the cowherd
built a prosperous life. Their farm flourished, and the weaver 
taught her skills to local villagers. As time marched on, the pair was 
blessed with two healthy children, but their bull was growing old. Before he died, the bull implored
the family to keep his hide and use its magic at their time of need. While the husband grieved for his friend, the weaver’s mind turned
to her other family. Dusting off her magical robe,
she decided to pay a visit to the heavens. But when the weaver
swept into her old home, no one seemed surprised to see her. With a start, she realized
that barely any time had passed— for a year on Earth
was merely a day in Heaven. When her family learned of her new life,
they were enraged. How dare she waste her love on a human? The weaver tried to escape back to Earth, but the Queen Mother plucked 
a golden hairpin from her head and tore through the sky. A great gulf opened, forming a river
of stars between Heaven and Earth. Below, the cowherd trembled, but he also
remembered the bull’s final words. Hastily placing each child in a basket, he draped the bull’s pelt
over his back and hurtled upwards. Above the clouds, each lover attempted
to wade through the surging stars. But no matter how hard they struggled, the gulf between them
only grew wider. Day after day, the Queen Mother
watched without pity. Years passed, and the weaver 
and the cowherd had no one, except the passing magpies 
to cheer them on. Finally, their love moved
the Queen Mother’s heart. While she couldn’t forgive
her granddaughter entirely, the Queen Mother would allow the weaver
to meet her earthly family once a year. And so, in late summer, the magpies
form a bridge across the Milky Way, reuniting the weaver and the cowherd. At this time of year, millions of people
in East and Southeast Asian countries tell similar tales of these 
star-crossed lovers, celebrating their annual reunion.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What did the cowherd come to the river to do?
Options: A. Pick grass for his bull, B. Sweep his parents’ graves, C. Swim, D. Read a book
Correct Option: B

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What was the special skill of the youngest princess in the celestial court of the Jade Emperor? Options: A. She could weave the most beautiful tapestries., B. She could pluck clouds from the sky and spin them into the softest robes., C. She could sing the most enchanting songs., D. She could create the most exquisite paintings. Correct Option: B
Question 2: Why did the weaver long for new inspiration in her craft? Options: A. She was tired of working with the same materials every day., B. She wanted to learn new techniques from the other princesses., C. Her work was the same day after day, and she yearned for something more., D. She was dissatisfied with the quality of her work. Correct Option: C
Question 3: What was the Queen Mother's condition for allowing the weaver to visit Earth? Options: A. She had to bring back a gift from Earth., B. She had to complete a task given by the Queen Mother., C. She had to promise to return to Heaven after a year., D. She had to meet the Queen Mother's expectations of her work. Correct Option: C
Question 4: What advice did the bull give to the cowherd about the weaver? Options: A. He told the cowherd to ignore the weaver and focus on his own life., B. He told the cowherd to be cautious around the weaver because she was from Heaven., C. He told the cowherd that the weaver could only remain on Earth if she lost her ticket back to Heaven., D. He told the cowherd to try to win the weaver's heart. Correct Option: C
Question 5: What was the consequence of the weaver's decision to stay on Earth? Options: A. She was able to return to Heaven and resume her life as a princess., B. She was able to live a happy life with the cowherd and their children., C. A great gulf opened between Heaven and Earth, making it difficult for her to return home., D. She was punished by the Queen Mother for disobeying her. Correct Option: C
Question 6: What did the bull ask the family to do with his hide before he died? Options: A. He asked them to bury him with it., B. He asked them to use its magic at their time of need., C. He asked them to give it to the weaver as a gift., D. He asked them to keep it as a reminder of their love. Correct Option: B
Question 7: What happened when the weaver returned to Heaven after being away for a year on Earth? Options: A. She was greeted as a hero by her family and friends., B. She was met with surprise by her family, who barely noticed her absence., C. She was punished by the Queen Mother for her disobedience., D. She was able to return to her life as a princess without any consequences. Correct Option: B
Question 8: What was the result of the weaver and the cowherd's love for each other? Options: A. The Queen Mother was moved to forgive the weaver and allow her to return to Earth., B. The weaver was able to live a happy life with the cowherd and their children, but only once a year., C. The weaver and the cowherd were able to be together in Heaven, but their love was not strong enough to overcome the gulf between them., D. The weaver and the cowherd were separated forever, and their love was forgotten. Correct Option: B
Question 9: What is the significance of the magpies forming a bridge across the Milky Way? Options: A. It is a sign of good luck and prosperity for the weaver and the cowherd., B. It is a reminder of the weaver's love for the cowher family in Heaven., C. It is a way for the weaver and the cowherd to be reunited once a year., D. It is a symbol of the Queen Mother's forgiveness and love for the weaver. Correct Option: C
Question 10: Why do millions of people in East and Southeast Asian countries tell similar tales of the weaver and the cowherd? Options: A. Because they believe in the power of true love to overcome any obstacle., B. Because they want to honor the weaver's bravery and determination., C. Because they celebrate the annual reunion of the weaver and the cowherd., D. Because they believe in the magic of the bull's hide. Correct Option: C


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is not explicitly present in the provided options. However, based on the context of the transcript, I can identify a question that is somewhat related to the ground truth MCQ.

The ground truth MCQ asks about the cowherd's reason for coming to the river. A similar question is not present in the generated MCQs. However, Question 4 mentions the cowherd and the weaver's encounter at the river, but it focuses on the bull's advice to the cowherd.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 1, Question 3
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
In the celestial court of the Jade Emperor
lived seven princesses. Each had their chosen place in court, but the youngest princess
had a special skill. She could pluck clouds from the sky
and spin them into the softest robes. Her work was so precise, not even the most expert eye
could find a seam. But her craft was the same day after day,
and she longed for new inspiration. Finally, the Queen Mother granted 
the weaver permission to visit Earth. The other princesses would accompany her to protect their sister 
from earthly dangers. Dressed in special robes that allowed them
to fly between Heaven and Earth, the sisters soared down from the sky. The weaver was in awe 
of the rolling hills and rivers, and the sisters decided to swim
in one of the glittering streams. As the weaver floated,
she dreamt about staying forever. Meanwhile, a lone cowherd
approached the riverbank. He came here often
to sweep his parent’s grave and speak with his only companion— a stoic bull who listened patiently 
to the cowherd’s sorrows. But upon seeing the weaver’s beauty,
the cowherd forgot his routine. While he longed to introduce himself,
his lonely lifestyle had made him timid. Thankfully, the bull saw his friend's
plight and offered some advice. He told the cowherd of the swimmer’s 
celestial origins and of her dream to stay on Earth; but also that she could only remain 
if she lost her ticket back to Heaven. As the cowherd approached,
the princesses flew away in fear— leaving their dreaming sister behind. While keeping her magic robes hidden, the cowherd offered his own garment 
as a substitute. And after gaining her trust, 
the pair began exploring the countryside. She was struck by his caring nature, and he learned to see 
the world’s wonder through her eyes. Before long, the two had
fallen deeply in love. The weaver and the cowherd
built a prosperous life. Their farm flourished, and the weaver 
taught her skills to local villagers. As time marched on, the pair was 
blessed with two healthy children, but their bull was growing old. Before he died, the bull implored
the family to keep his hide and use its magic at their time of need. While the husband grieved for his friend, the weaver’s mind turned
to her other family. Dusting off her magical robe,
she decided to pay a visit to the heavens. But when the weaver
swept into her old home, no one seemed surprised to see her. With a start, she realized
that barely any time had passed— for a year on Earth
was merely a day in Heaven. When her family learned of her new life,
they were enraged. How dare she waste her love on a human? The weaver tried to escape back to Earth, but the Queen Mother plucked 
a golden hairpin from her head and tore through the sky. A great gulf opened, forming a river
of stars between Heaven and Earth. Below, the cowherd trembled, but he also
remembered the bull’s final words. Hastily placing each child in a basket, he draped the bull’s pelt
over his back and hurtled upwards. Above the clouds, each lover attempted
to wade through the surging stars. But no matter how hard they struggled, the gulf between them
only grew wider. Day after day, the Queen Mother
watched without pity. Years passed, and the weaver 
and the cowherd had no one, except the passing magpies 
to cheer them on. Finally, their love moved
the Queen Mother’s heart. While she couldn’t forgive
her granddaughter entirely, the Queen Mother would allow the weaver
to meet her earthly family once a year. And so, in late summer, the magpies
form a bridge across the Milky Way, reuniting the weaver and the cowherd. At this time of year, millions of people
in East and Southeast Asian countries tell similar tales of these 
star-crossed lovers, celebrating their annual reunion.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What did the cowherd use to fly up to heaven?
Options: A. The weaver’s clothing, B. A pair of baskets, C. A flock of birds, D. The bull’s pelt
Correct Option: D

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 1, Question 4
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
In the celestial court of the Jade Emperor
lived seven princesses. Each had their chosen place in court, but the youngest princess
had a special skill. She could pluck clouds from the sky
and spin them into the softest robes. Her work was so precise, not even the most expert eye
could find a seam. But her craft was the same day after day,
and she longed for new inspiration. Finally, the Queen Mother granted 
the weaver permission to visit Earth. The other princesses would accompany her to protect their sister 
from earthly dangers. Dressed in special robes that allowed them
to fly between Heaven and Earth, the sisters soared down from the sky. The weaver was in awe 
of the rolling hills and rivers, and the sisters decided to swim
in one of the glittering streams. As the weaver floated,
she dreamt about staying forever. Meanwhile, a lone cowherd
approached the riverbank. He came here often
to sweep his parent’s grave and speak with his only companion— a stoic bull who listened patiently 
to the cowherd’s sorrows. But upon seeing the weaver’s beauty,
the cowherd forgot his routine. While he longed to introduce himself,
his lonely lifestyle had made him timid. Thankfully, the bull saw his friend's
plight and offered some advice. He told the cowherd of the swimmer’s 
celestial origins and of her dream to stay on Earth; but also that she could only remain 
if she lost her ticket back to Heaven. As the cowherd approached,
the princesses flew away in fear— leaving their dreaming sister behind. While keeping her magic robes hidden, the cowherd offered his own garment 
as a substitute. And after gaining her trust, 
the pair began exploring the countryside. She was struck by his caring nature, and he learned to see 
the world’s wonder through her eyes. Before long, the two had
fallen deeply in love. The weaver and the cowherd
built a prosperous life. Their farm flourished, and the weaver 
taught her skills to local villagers. As time marched on, the pair was 
blessed with two healthy children, but their bull was growing old. Before he died, the bull implored
the family to keep his hide and use its magic at their time of need. While the husband grieved for his friend, the weaver’s mind turned
to her other family. Dusting off her magical robe,
she decided to pay a visit to the heavens. But when the weaver
swept into her old home, no one seemed surprised to see her. With a start, she realized
that barely any time had passed— for a year on Earth
was merely a day in Heaven. When her family learned of her new life,
they were enraged. How dare she waste her love on a human? The weaver tried to escape back to Earth, but the Queen Mother plucked 
a golden hairpin from her head and tore through the sky. A great gulf opened, forming a river
of stars between Heaven and Earth. Below, the cowherd trembled, but he also
remembered the bull’s final words. Hastily placing each child in a basket, he draped the bull’s pelt
over his back and hurtled upwards. Above the clouds, each lover attempted
to wade through the surging stars. But no matter how hard they struggled, the gulf between them
only grew wider. Day after day, the Queen Mother
watched without pity. Years passed, and the weaver 
and the cowherd had no one, except the passing magpies 
to cheer them on. Finally, their love moved
the Queen Mother’s heart. While she couldn’t forgive
her granddaughter entirely, the Queen Mother would allow the weaver
to meet her earthly family once a year. And so, in late summer, the magpies
form a bridge across the Milky Way, reuniting the weaver and the cowherd. At this time of year, millions of people
in East and Southeast Asian countries tell similar tales of these 
star-crossed lovers, celebrating their annual reunion.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: By the Queen Mother’s decree, the weaver and cowherd could meet _____.
Options: A. Once a day, B. Once a year, C. Once every 10 years, D. Never
Correct Option: B

Question 1: What was the special skill of the youngest princess in the celestial court of the Jade Emperor? Options: A. She could weave the most beautiful tapestries., B. She could pluck clouds from the sky and spin them into the softest robes., C. She could sing the most enchanting songs., D. She could create the most exquisite paintings. Correct Option: B

She wanted to learn new techniques from the other princesses., C. Her work was the same day after day, and she yearned for something more., D. She was dissatisfied with the quality of her work. Correct Option: C

Question 4: What advice did the bull give to the cowherd about the weaver? Options: A. He told the cowherd to ignore the weaver and focus on his own life., B. He told the cowherd to be cautious around the weaver because she was from Heaven., C. He told the cowherd that the weaver could only remain on Earth if she lost her ticket back to Heaven., D. He told the cowherd to try to win the weaver's heart. Correct Option: C

She was able to live a happy life with the cowherd and their children., C. A great gulf opened between Heaven and Earth, making it difficult for her to return home., D. She was punished by the Queen Mother for disobeying her. Correct Option: C

He asked them to give it to the weaver as a gift., D. He asked them to keep it as a reminder of their love. Correct Option: B
Question 7: What happened when the weaver returned to Heaven after being away for a year on Earth? Options: A. She was greeted as a hero by her family and friends., B. She was met with surprise by her family, who barely noticed her absence., C. She was punished by the Queen Mother for her disobedience., D. She was able to return to her life as a princess without any consequences. Correct Option: B
Question 8: What was the result of the weaver and the cowherd's love for each other? Options: A. The Queen Mother was moved to forgive the weaver and allow her to return to Earth., B. The weaver was able to live a happy life with the cowherd and their children, but only once a year., C. The weaver and the cowherd were able to be together in Heaven, but their love was not strong enough to overcome the gulf between them., D. The weaver and the cowherd were separated forever, and their love was forgotten. Correct Option: B
Question 9: What is the significance of the magpies forming a bridge across the Milky Way? Options: A. It is a sign of good luck and prosperity for the weaver and the cowherd., B. It is a reminder of the weaver's love for the cowher family in Heaven., C. It is a way for the weaver and the cowherd to be reunited once a year., D. It is a symbol of the Queen Mother's forgiveness and love for the weaver. Correct Option: C
Question 10: Why do millions of people in East and Southeast Asian countries tell similar tales of the weaver and the cowherd? Options: A. Because they believe in the power of true love to overcome any obstacle., B. Because they want to honor the weaver's bravery and determination., C. Because they celebrate the annual reunion of the weaver and the cowherd., D. Because they believe in the magic of the bull's hide. Correct Option: C


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 8. 

This question has a similar intent to the ground truth MCQ, as it asks about the result of the weaver and the cowherd's love for each other, specifically in relation to the Queen Mother's actions. The correct option, B, states that the weaver is able to live a happy life with the cowherd and their children, but only once a year, which matches the ground truth MCQ's correct option, B, "Once a year".

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 1, Question 5
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
In the celestial court of the Jade Emperor
lived seven princesses. Each had their chosen place in court, but the youngest princess
had a special skill. She could pluck clouds from the sky
and spin them into the softest robes. Her work was so precise, not even the most expert eye
could find a seam. But her craft was the same day after day,
and she longed for new inspiration. Finally, the Queen Mother granted 
the weaver permission to visit Earth. The other princesses would accompany her to protect their sister 
from earthly dangers. Dressed in special robes that allowed them
to fly between Heaven and Earth, the sisters soared down from the sky. The weaver was in awe 
of the rolling hills and rivers, and the sisters decided to swim
in one of the glittering streams. As the weaver floated,
she dreamt about staying forever. Meanwhile, a lone cowherd
approached the riverbank. He came here often
to sweep his parent’s grave and speak with his only companion— a stoic bull who listened patiently 
to the cowherd’s sorrows. But upon seeing the weaver’s beauty,
the cowherd forgot his routine. While he longed to introduce himself,
his lonely lifestyle had made him timid. Thankfully, the bull saw his friend's
plight and offered some advice. He told the cowherd of the swimmer’s 
celestial origins and of her dream to stay on Earth; but also that she could only remain 
if she lost her ticket back to Heaven. As the cowherd approached,
the princesses flew away in fear— leaving their dreaming sister behind. While keeping her magic robes hidden, the cowherd offered his own garment 
as a substitute. And after gaining her trust, 
the pair began exploring the countryside. She was struck by his caring nature, and he learned to see 
the world’s wonder through her eyes. Before long, the two had
fallen deeply in love. The weaver and the cowherd
built a prosperous life. Their farm flourished, and the weaver 
taught her skills to local villagers. As time marched on, the pair was 
blessed with two healthy children, but their bull was growing old. Before he died, the bull implored
the family to keep his hide and use its magic at their time of need. While the husband grieved for his friend, the weaver’s mind turned
to her other family. Dusting off her magical robe,
she decided to pay a visit to the heavens. But when the weaver
swept into her old home, no one seemed surprised to see her. With a start, she realized
that barely any time had passed— for a year on Earth
was merely a day in Heaven. When her family learned of her new life,
they were enraged. How dare she waste her love on a human? The weaver tried to escape back to Earth, but the Queen Mother plucked 
a golden hairpin from her head and tore through the sky. A great gulf opened, forming a river
of stars between Heaven and Earth. Below, the cowherd trembled, but he also
remembered the bull’s final words. Hastily placing each child in a basket, he draped the bull’s pelt
over his back and hurtled upwards. Above the clouds, each lover attempted
to wade through the surging stars. But no matter how hard they struggled, the gulf between them
only grew wider. Day after day, the Queen Mother
watched without pity. Years passed, and the weaver 
and the cowherd had no one, except the passing magpies 
to cheer them on. Finally, their love moved
the Queen Mother’s heart. While she couldn’t forgive
her granddaughter entirely, the Queen Mother would allow the weaver
to meet her earthly family once a year. And so, in late summer, the magpies
form a bridge across the Milky Way, reuniting the weaver and the cowherd. At this time of year, millions of people
in East and Southeast Asian countries tell similar tales of these 
star-crossed lovers, celebrating their annual reunion.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Which birds help the weaver and cowherd reunite?
Options: A. magpies   , B. swans, C. crows, D. doves
Correct Option: A

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 2, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
As Numberland’s best detective,
you thought you’d seen it all. But the desiccated corpses 
of prominent natural numbers— whole numbers greater than 0— have been showing up all over the city
for the past week. All of Digitopolis is on lockdown
from sundown to sunrise, and it’s still not enough to stop
what can only be described as a vampiric feeding frenzy. The police are helpless, 
and have turned to you. You put the missing persons case 
you’ve been investigating on hold and study the evidence. Here’s what you know: most victims have been completely
drained of their life’s essence. Some have a thin line of slime
separating digits— some of which were drained 
and others spared. Which leads you to mystery one: what’s the significance 
of the slime-lines, and why are certain digits untouched? Pause here to figure it out yourself. 
Answer in 3 Answer in 2 Answer in 1 Let’s start by looking 
for a pattern in the victims. Why have some been fully drained,
and some slimed? Well, the slime-lined are in their prime— which is to say they’re prime numbers,
divisible only by 1 and themselves. Not a single one of the unslimed numbers,
on the other hand, is. Furthermore, the drained parts of the 
slimed primes are not, themselves, prime. When 71 got slimed, 7 was prime,
but 1 was not. If 461 had been split into 4 and 61,
the right side would have been prime, but instead it was split further
into non-prime digits. And when 2099 got slimed, 
the attacker went with 20 and 99, and was able to drain both. So you have a big problem. There are infinite potential victims: all non-prime numbers, and all prime numbers that can 
be slime-lined to reveal at least one non-prime number. In fact, you can only think of a few
numbers that aren't vulnerable. First of all, the one digit primes: 
2, 3, 5, and 7. Then primes like 23, which could only be
split into 2 and 3, both prime. These numbers are familiar, but why? Aha! Your missing person’s case. Someone is kidnapping the numbers
that can’t be drained: we’ll call them the immune. If you can identify the four immune 
who remain, perhaps you can get to them first
and figure out what’s going on. Who are the immune?
Pause here to figure it out yourself. Answer in 2 Answer in 1 There are 4 one-digit immune:
2, 3, 5, and 7. All have already been kidnapped. But every digit in all of the immune
must be one of those four numbers; otherwise there would be 
a non-prime split possible. That means there are only these 16
candidates among the two-digit numbers. The ones that are prime must be immune. We can eliminate anything 
that ends in 2 or 5, as they’ll always be divisible by 2 and 5. This diagonal is also out,
as they’re divisible by 11. If the digits of a number add
up to a multiple of 3, it’s divisible by 3. So that eliminates 57 and 27,
leaving these numbers. Which, upon double-checking, are, 
in fact, immune. We now have a strong starting point
for searching three-digit numbers: any 2 consecutive digits must be 
on the list of the two-digit immune. Those all end in 3 and 7, so the only possibilities
are these 8 options: the two-digit immune with additional
3s or 7s on their ends. 3 can’t follow 3,
nor 7 follow 7. And once again, adding the digits 
reveals that 237 and 537 are divisible by 3. 737 is 67 times 11, 
so that leaves just 373, which is, in fact, prime,
and therefore immune. Could a four-digit number be immune? No, any consecutive three digits
would have to be immune, and there’s no immune three digit
number that starts with a 7. You rush out, 
but reach each home too late, until the only immune left is 373. You’re in the nick of time to scare
off her would-be kidnapper; not the vampire itself but a minion. 373 explains that she and the other immune
are the subjects of an ancient prophecy that designated them as vampire slayers. They’d sometimes gather and try 
to figure out what a vampire is, but no one had the slightest idea. They found the idea of slaying
things quite distasteful. You both trail her would-be kidnapper
back to a foreboding castle. There you release the other 
kidnapped numbers and confront the vampire himself. He’s powerless before the slayers, 
but ever the pacifists, they round him up, return the lifeforce 
to his victims, and send him packing. Numberland is safe... for now.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Which one of these statements is true?
Options: A. 1 is a prime number., B. All prime numbers are odd., C. 2, 3, 5, and 7 are the only one-digit primes.
Correct Option: C

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is not the best question to ask in a detective investigation? Options: A. A question that is too broad or vague, B. A question that is too narrow or specific, C. A question that is irrelevant to the topic, D. A question that is poorly phrased Correct Option: A
Question 2: What is the main problem that the detective is trying to solve in the story? Options: A. A series of missing persons cases, B. A vampire that is feeding on numbers, C. A mystery surrounding the slime-lined numbers, D. A prophecy about vampire slayers Correct Option: B
Question 3: What is the significance of the slime-lines in the story? Options: A. They indicate that a number is non-prime, B. They indicate that a number has been drained of its life's essence, C. They indicate that a number is prime and can be drained, D. They are a random occurrence Correct Option: B
Question 4: Which numbers are immune to the vampire and cannot be drained? Options: A. Non-prime numbers, B. Prime numbers, C. Numbers that can be split into non-prime digits, D. One-digit prime numbers, such as 2, 3, 5, and 7 Correct Option: D
Question 5: What is the process that the detective uses to identify the immune numbers? Options: A. They look for numbers that are divisible by 11, B. They look for numbers that add up to a multiple of 3, C. They eliminate numbers that end in 2 or 5, D. They use a combination of these methods to narrow down the possibilities Correct Option: D
Question 6: What is the result of the detective's investigation and the vampire's confrontation with the immune numbers? Options: A. The vampire is killed, B. The vampire is sent packing, C. The vampire is powerless and the immune numbers round him up, D. The vampire is still at large Correct Option: C
Question 7: What is the significance of the prophecy about the vampire slayers? Options: A. It indicates that the vampire is invincible, B. It indicates that the vampire is powerless against the immune numbers, C. It indicates that the immune numbers are destined to slay the vampire, D. It has no significance in the story Correct Option: C
Question 8: What is the setting of the story? Options: A. A city called Digitopolis, B. A castle, C. A numberland, D. A city called Numberland Correct Option: A
Question 9: What is the main theme of the story? Options: A. The power of numbers, B. The power of prophecy, C. The struggle between good and evil, D. The power of the immune numbers Correct Option: C
Question 10: What is the tone of the story? Options: A. Dark and ominous, B. Light and humorous, C. Serious and suspenseful, D. All of the above Correct Option: C


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 4. 

This question asks about the numbers that are immune to the vampire and cannot be drained, with the correct option being one-digit prime numbers, such as 2, 3, 5, and 7. This matches the content and intent of the ground truth MCQ, which asks about the truth of the statement that 2, 3, 5, and 7 are the only one-digit primes.

Index of the most similar generated MCQ: 4.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: The vampire’s victims are:
Options: A. Only prime numbers., B. Only numbers that are not prime., C. A mix of primes and non-primes.
Correct Option: C

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 4. However, the options provided in Question 4 do not exactly match the ground truth MCQ. 

A more accurate match would be a question that asks about the nature of the vampire's victims, which is not explicitly present in the generated MCQs. However, based on the available options, Question 4 is the closest match.

But if we consider the content of each generated question, Question 3 is somewhat related to the vampire's victims as it discusses the significance of the slime-lines, which is connected to the type of numbers that are being drained.

However, upon closer inspection, we can see that Question 2 is a better match because it asks about the main problem the detective is trying to solve, which is related to the vampire's victims.

So the correct answer would be Question 2's index, but only if we consider the broader context of the question and not the exact wording.

However, I must note that none of the generated MCQs perfectly match the ground truth MCQ in terms of question intent, options, and content.

With that said, if I had to choose the most similar generated MCQ, I would choose Question 2's index.

The index of the most similar generated MCQ is: 2

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 2, Question 3
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
As Numberland’s best detective,
you thought you’d seen it all. But the desiccated corpses 
of prominent natural numbers— whole numbers greater than 0— have been showing up all over the city
for the past week. All of Digitopolis is on lockdown
from sundown to sunrise, and it’s still not enough to stop
what can only be described as a vampiric feeding frenzy. The police are helpless, 
and have turned to you. You put the missing persons case 
you’ve been investigating on hold and study the evidence. Here’s what you know: most victims have been completely
drained of their life’s essence. Some have a thin line of slime
separating digits— some of which were drained 
and others spared. Which leads you to mystery one: what’s the significance 
of the slime-lines, and why are certain digits untouched? Pause here to figure it out yourself. 
Answer in 3 Answer in 2 Answer in 1 Let’s start by looking 
for a pattern in the victims. Why have some been fully drained,
and some slimed? Well, the slime-lined are in their prime— which is to say they’re prime numbers,
divisible only by 1 and themselves. Not a single one of the unslimed numbers,
on the other hand, is. Furthermore, the drained parts of the 
slimed primes are not, themselves, prime. When 71 got slimed, 7 was prime,
but 1 was not. If 461 had been split into 4 and 61,
the right side would have been prime, but instead it was split further
into non-prime digits. And when 2099 got slimed, 
the attacker went with 20 and 99, and was able to drain both. So you have a big problem. There are infinite potential victims: all non-prime numbers, and all prime numbers that can 
be slime-lined to reveal at least one non-prime number. In fact, you can only think of a few
numbers that aren't vulnerable. First of all, the one digit primes: 
2, 3, 5, and 7. Then primes like 23, which could only be
split into 2 and 3, both prime. These numbers are familiar, but why? Aha! Your missing person’s case. Someone is kidnapping the numbers
that can’t be drained: we’ll call them the immune. If you can identify the four immune 
who remain, perhaps you can get to them first
and figure out what’s going on. Who are the immune?
Pause here to figure it out yourself. Answer in 2 Answer in 1 There are 4 one-digit immune:
2, 3, 5, and 7. All have already been kidnapped. But every digit in all of the immune
must be one of those four numbers; otherwise there would be 
a non-prime split possible. That means there are only these 16
candidates among the two-digit numbers. The ones that are prime must be immune. We can eliminate anything 
that ends in 2 or 5, as they’ll always be divisible by 2 and 5. This diagonal is also out,
as they’re divisible by 11. If the digits of a number add
up to a multiple of 3, it’s divisible by 3. So that eliminates 57 and 27,
leaving these numbers. Which, upon double-checking, are, 
in fact, immune. We now have a strong starting point
for searching three-digit numbers: any 2 consecutive digits must be 
on the list of the two-digit immune. Those all end in 3 and 7, so the only possibilities
are these 8 options: the two-digit immune with additional
3s or 7s on their ends. 3 can’t follow 3,
nor 7 follow 7. And once again, adding the digits 
reveals that 237 and 537 are divisible by 3. 737 is 67 times 11, 
so that leaves just 373, which is, in fact, prime,
and therefore immune. Could a four-digit number be immune? No, any consecutive three digits
would have to be immune, and there’s no immune three digit
number that starts with a 7. You rush out, 
but reach each home too late, until the only immune left is 373. You’re in the nick of time to scare
off her would-be kidnapper; not the vampire itself but a minion. 373 explains that she and the other immune
are the subjects of an ancient prophecy that designated them as vampire slayers. They’d sometimes gather and try 
to figure out what a vampire is, but no one had the slightest idea. They found the idea of slaying
things quite distasteful. You both trail her would-be kidnapper
back to a foreboding castle. There you release the other 
kidnapped numbers and confront the vampire himself. He’s powerless before the slayers, 
but ever the pacifists, they round him up, return the lifeforce 
to his victims, and send him packing. Numberland is safe... for now.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Prime number victims have:
Options: A. Slime lines separating their digits., B. Only odd digits., C. Only even digits.
Correct Option: A

Question 3: What is the significance of the slime-lines in the story? Options: A. They indicate that a number is non-prime, B. They indicate that a number has been drained of its life's essence, C. They indicate that a number is prime and can be drained, D. They are a random occurrence Correct Option: B
Question 4: Which numbers are immune to the vampire and cannot be drained? Options: A. Non-prime numbers, B. Prime numbers, C. Numbers that can be split into non-prime digits, D. One-digit prime numbers, such as 2, 3, 5, and 7 Correct Option: D
Question 5: What is the process that the detective uses to identify the immune numbers? Options: A. They look for numbers that are divisible by 11, B. They look for numbers that add up to a multiple of 3, C. They eliminate numbers that end in 2 or 5, D. They use a combination of these methods to narrow down the possibilities Correct Option: D

Question 10: What is the tone of the story? Options: A. Dark and ominous, B. Light and humorous, C. Serious and suspenseful, D. All of the above Correct Option: C

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 2, Question 4
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
As Numberland’s best detective,
you thought you’d seen it all. But the desiccated corpses 
of prominent natural numbers— whole numbers greater than 0— have been showing up all over the city
for the past week. All of Digitopolis is on lockdown
from sundown to sunrise, and it’s still not enough to stop
what can only be described as a vampiric feeding frenzy. The police are helpless, 
and have turned to you. You put the missing persons case 
you’ve been investigating on hold and study the evidence. Here’s what you know: most victims have been completely
drained of their life’s essence. Some have a thin line of slime
separating digits— some of which were drained 
and others spared. Which leads you to mystery one: what’s the significance 
of the slime-lines, and why are certain digits untouched? Pause here to figure it out yourself. 
Answer in 3 Answer in 2 Answer in 1 Let’s start by looking 
for a pattern in the victims. Why have some been fully drained,
and some slimed? Well, the slime-lined are in their prime— which is to say they’re prime numbers,
divisible only by 1 and themselves. Not a single one of the unslimed numbers,
on the other hand, is. Furthermore, the drained parts of the 
slimed primes are not, themselves, prime. When 71 got slimed, 7 was prime,
but 1 was not. If 461 had been split into 4 and 61,
the right side would have been prime, but instead it was split further
into non-prime digits. And when 2099 got slimed, 
the attacker went with 20 and 99, and was able to drain both. So you have a big problem. There are infinite potential victims: all non-prime numbers, and all prime numbers that can 
be slime-lined to reveal at least one non-prime number. In fact, you can only think of a few
numbers that aren't vulnerable. First of all, the one digit primes: 
2, 3, 5, and 7. Then primes like 23, which could only be
split into 2 and 3, both prime. These numbers are familiar, but why? Aha! Your missing person’s case. Someone is kidnapping the numbers
that can’t be drained: we’ll call them the immune. If you can identify the four immune 
who remain, perhaps you can get to them first
and figure out what’s going on. Who are the immune?
Pause here to figure it out yourself. Answer in 2 Answer in 1 There are 4 one-digit immune:
2, 3, 5, and 7. All have already been kidnapped. But every digit in all of the immune
must be one of those four numbers; otherwise there would be 
a non-prime split possible. That means there are only these 16
candidates among the two-digit numbers. The ones that are prime must be immune. We can eliminate anything 
that ends in 2 or 5, as they’ll always be divisible by 2 and 5. This diagonal is also out,
as they’re divisible by 11. If the digits of a number add
up to a multiple of 3, it’s divisible by 3. So that eliminates 57 and 27,
leaving these numbers. Which, upon double-checking, are, 
in fact, immune. We now have a strong starting point
for searching three-digit numbers: any 2 consecutive digits must be 
on the list of the two-digit immune. Those all end in 3 and 7, so the only possibilities
are these 8 options: the two-digit immune with additional
3s or 7s on their ends. 3 can’t follow 3,
nor 7 follow 7. And once again, adding the digits 
reveals that 237 and 537 are divisible by 3. 737 is 67 times 11, 
so that leaves just 373, which is, in fact, prime,
and therefore immune. Could a four-digit number be immune? No, any consecutive three digits
would have to be immune, and there’s no immune three digit
number that starts with a 7. You rush out, 
but reach each home too late, until the only immune left is 373. You’re in the nick of time to scare
off her would-be kidnapper; not the vampire itself but a minion. 373 explains that she and the other immune
are the subjects of an ancient prophecy that designated them as vampire slayers. They’d sometimes gather and try 
to figure out what a vampire is, but no one had the slightest idea. They found the idea of slaying
things quite distasteful. You both trail her would-be kidnapper
back to a foreboding castle. There you release the other 
kidnapped numbers and confront the vampire himself. He’s powerless before the slayers, 
but ever the pacifists, they round him up, return the lifeforce 
to his victims, and send him packing. Numberland is safe... for now.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: The vampire’s goal with the slime lines is to:
Options: A. Scare his victims., B. Isolate prime sequences in order to drain them., C. Isolate non-prime sequences in order to drain them.
Correct Option: C

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 3, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
In the Egyptian Book of the Dead,
there’s a banishment spell that declares, “Be far from me, 
O vile cockroach.” More than 3,000 years later, 
we’re still trying to oust these insects. But from poison traps 
to hastily brandished slippers, cockroaches seem to weather 
just about everything we throw at them. So what makes cockroaches so hard to kill? There are nearly 5,000 cockroach species. 99% of them live in a range of habitats
where they play important ecological roles by recycling dead or decaying 
organic matter and nourishing other animals. But a couple dozen species adapted to live
in close association with humans. German and American cockroaches
are among the most common. And they owe their resilience
to a combination of physical and chemical adaptations. When it comes to old-fashioned 
removal methods, they're troublingly tenacious. An American cockroach’s sensory hairs 
or structures pick up subtle air currents and rapidly send signals 
to its central nervous system. The roach can then turn and sprint
away within a few milliseconds. And it’s among the fastest invertebrates
ever recorded, reaching speeds of up to 50
body lengths per second. This would be the human equivalent of
running more than 300 kilometers per hour. And finding a hiding place is no problem. With its flattened, flexible body, an American cockroach can squeeze into 
spaces less than a quarter of its height. Even if we do land a hit, 
it can withstand compressive forces of up to 900 times its own weight 
by distributing the impact along its body. And the cockroach’s toughness
doesn’t end there. Cockroaches can eat a variety 
of organic matter, including hair, dead skin, 
adhesives, and paper. This is made possible by an expansive set 
of digestive enzymes. Cockroaches are able to thrive 
even in nutrient-poor environments. Roaches often eat decaying foods
that are low in nitrogen— an essential component
of DNA and proteins. But they survive by storing 
nitrogen-containing wastes in their bodies and having a resident group
of bacteria recycle the nitrogen into useful molecules for them. Meanwhile, German cockroaches
will eat their own poop, vomit, and dead or dying colony members 
without hesitation. An American cockroach will
frolic in sewers, consuming excrement and toting microbes
like Staphylococcus aureus and E.coli. But they’ll rarely suffer
any consequences. This is because they’re equipped 
with genes that provide immunity against numerous pathogens. These genes are often duplicated 
many times over. So when infected, the cockroach’s 
immune system efficiently unleashes many antimicrobial molecules. Cockroaches also have a slew of defenses
against pesticides. When a non-resistant roach walks 
on a surface that’s been sprayed with a pyrethroid insecticide, 
for example, the results will likely be fatal. Once absorbed, the chemical binds
to sodium channel proteins, which help propagate nerve impulses. The pyrethroid keeps 
the sodium channels open, so the nerves fire repeatedly. And soon, the cockroach dies. But if a resistant roach is exposed 
to pyrethroids, it’ll be just fine. Genetic mutations have given
them sodium channels that the pyrethroids can’t bind to. The cockroach also produces more
detoxification enzymes, which render the pesticide harmless, and the cockroach simply excretes 
it as a waste. Because German cockroaches
reproduce especially quickly, populations may evolve resistance 
to a new pesticide within months. So far, they're already resistant
to 43 different chemicals. But contrary to popular belief, cockroaches would probably not survive 
a nuclear apocalypse. Compared with other insects, cockroaches are only mildly
tolerant to radiation. They would die near the sites
of nuclear explosions and would still be severely
compromised miles away. Moreover, disasters that threaten humanity also jeopardize the habitats and buffets 
we provide roaches. Perhaps the only way to beat them 
is through our mutual destruction. Or maybe cockroaches would find 
even more surprising ways to thrive long after we’re gone.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Which factors do cockroaches owe their resilience to?
Options: A. Physical and chemical adaptations, B. Environmental factors, C. Psychiatric factors, D. None of the above
Correct Option: A

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: How many cockroach species exist? Options: A. 1,000, B. 3,000, C. Nearly 5,000, D. 10,000 Correct Option: C
Question 2: What is one of the primary ecological roles of cockroaches in their habitats? Options: A. To prey on other animals, B. To recycle dead or decaying organic matter, C. To pollinate plants, D. To produce honey Correct Option: B
Question 3: What is the estimated speed of an American cockroach in terms of human equivalent speed? Options: A. 50 kilometers per hour, B. 100 kilometers per hour, C. More than 300 kilometers per hour, D. 500 kilometers per hour Correct Option: C
Question 4: What is one of the physical adaptations that allows an American cockroach to evade predators? Options: A. Its ability to fly, B. Its ability to swim, C. Its sensory hairs or structures that pick up subtle air currents, D. Its camouflage abilities Correct Option: C
Question 5: What is one of the unique features of a cockroach's digestive system? Options: A. Its ability to digest only plant-based materials, B. Its ability to store nitrogen-containing wastes in its body, C. Its ability to produce digestive enzymes that break down a wide range of organic matter, D. Its ability to absorb nutrients through its skin Correct Option: C
Question 6: What is one of the ways in which cockroaches can recycle nitrogen in their bodies? Options: A. By storing it in their muscles, B. By excreting it as waste, C. By having a resident group of bacteria recycle the nitrogen into useful molecules, D. By absorbing it from the air Correct Option: C
Question 7: What is one of the reasons why cockroaches are able to thrive in environments with low levels of nitrogen? Options: A. Because they are able to absorb nitrogen from the air, B. Because they are able to store nitrogen in their bodies, C. Because they have a unique set of digestive enzymes that allow them to break down nitrogen-poor materials, D. Because they are able to produce their own nitrogen Correct Option: C
Question 8: What is one of the ways in which cockroaches are able to defend themselves against pesticides? Options: A. By producing more detoxification enzymes, B. By having a thicker exoskeleton, C. By being able to fly away quickly, D. By being able to hide in small spaces Correct Option: A
Question 9: What is one of the reasons why German cockroaches are able to evolve resistance to pesticides so quickly? Options: A. Because they are able to adapt to changing environments, B. Because they are able to reproduce quickly, C. Because they are able to communicate with each other, D. Because they are able to absorb nutrients from the air Correct Option: B
Question 10: What is one of the reasons why cockroaches would likely not survive a nuclear apocalypse? Options: A. Because they are able to withstand high levels of radiation, B. Because they are able to fly away quickly, C. Because their habitats and food sources would be severely compromised, D. Because they are able to adapt to changing environments Correct Option: C


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
None of the generated MCQs directly match the ground truth MCQ in terms of question content and options. However, based on the question intent, which is to understand the factors that contribute to the resilience of cockroaches, the most similar generated MCQ would be:

Question 4: What is one of the physical adaptations that allows an American cockroach to evade predators?

However, this question only addresses one aspect of the ground truth MCQ, which is the physical adaptations of cockroaches.

A more comprehensive match would be a generated MCQ that addresses both physical and chemical adaptations, but such a question is not present in the provided set.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 3, Question 2
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
In the Egyptian Book of the Dead,
there’s a banishment spell that declares, “Be far from me, 
O vile cockroach.” More than 3,000 years later, 
we’re still trying to oust these insects. But from poison traps 
to hastily brandished slippers, cockroaches seem to weather 
just about everything we throw at them. So what makes cockroaches so hard to kill? There are nearly 5,000 cockroach species. 99% of them live in a range of habitats
where they play important ecological roles by recycling dead or decaying 
organic matter and nourishing other animals. But a couple dozen species adapted to live
in close association with humans. German and American cockroaches
are among the most common. And they owe their resilience
to a combination of physical and chemical adaptations. When it comes to old-fashioned 
removal methods, they're troublingly tenacious. An American cockroach’s sensory hairs 
or structures pick up subtle air currents and rapidly send signals 
to its central nervous system. The roach can then turn and sprint
away within a few milliseconds. And it’s among the fastest invertebrates
ever recorded, reaching speeds of up to 50
body lengths per second. This would be the human equivalent of
running more than 300 kilometers per hour. And finding a hiding place is no problem. With its flattened, flexible body, an American cockroach can squeeze into 
spaces less than a quarter of its height. Even if we do land a hit, 
it can withstand compressive forces of up to 900 times its own weight 
by distributing the impact along its body. And the cockroach’s toughness
doesn’t end there. Cockroaches can eat a variety 
of organic matter, including hair, dead skin, 
adhesives, and paper. This is made possible by an expansive set 
of digestive enzymes. Cockroaches are able to thrive 
even in nutrient-poor environments. Roaches often eat decaying foods
that are low in nitrogen— an essential component
of DNA and proteins. But they survive by storing 
nitrogen-containing wastes in their bodies and having a resident group
of bacteria recycle the nitrogen into useful molecules for them. Meanwhile, German cockroaches
will eat their own poop, vomit, and dead or dying colony members 
without hesitation. An American cockroach will
frolic in sewers, consuming excrement and toting microbes
like Staphylococcus aureus and E.coli. But they’ll rarely suffer
any consequences. This is because they’re equipped 
with genes that provide immunity against numerous pathogens. These genes are often duplicated 
many times over. So when infected, the cockroach’s 
immune system efficiently unleashes many antimicrobial molecules. Cockroaches also have a slew of defenses
against pesticides. When a non-resistant roach walks 
on a surface that’s been sprayed with a pyrethroid insecticide, 
for example, the results will likely be fatal. Once absorbed, the chemical binds
to sodium channel proteins, which help propagate nerve impulses. The pyrethroid keeps 
the sodium channels open, so the nerves fire repeatedly. And soon, the cockroach dies. But if a resistant roach is exposed 
to pyrethroids, it’ll be just fine. Genetic mutations have given
them sodium channels that the pyrethroids can’t bind to. The cockroach also produces more
detoxification enzymes, which render the pesticide harmless, and the cockroach simply excretes 
it as a waste. Because German cockroaches
reproduce especially quickly, populations may evolve resistance 
to a new pesticide within months. So far, they're already resistant
to 43 different chemicals. But contrary to popular belief, cockroaches would probably not survive 
a nuclear apocalypse. Compared with other insects, cockroaches are only mildly
tolerant to radiation. They would die near the sites
of nuclear explosions and would still be severely
compromised miles away. Moreover, disasters that threaten humanity also jeopardize the habitats and buffets 
we provide roaches. Perhaps the only way to beat them 
is through our mutual destruction. Or maybe cockroaches would find 
even more surprising ways to thrive long after we’re gone.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: The ability of pest cockroaches such as the American cockroach to escape stomping attempts by humans can be attributed to which of the following characteristics.
Options: A. Walking or running speed, B. Flattened and flexible body, C. Both “a” and “b”, D. None of the above
Correct Option: C

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: How many cockroach species exist? Options: A. 1,000, B. 3,000, C. Nearly 5,000, D. 10,000 Correct Option: C
Question 2: What is one of the primary ecological roles of cockroaches in their habitats? Options: A. To prey on other animals, B. To recycle dead or decaying organic matter, C. To pollinate plants, D. To produce honey Correct Option: B
Question 3: What is the estimated speed of an American cockroach in terms of human equivalent speed? Options: A. 50 kilometers per hour, B. 100 kilometers per hour, C. More than 300 kilometers per hour, D. 500 kilometers per hour Correct Option: C
Question 4: What is one of the physical adaptations that allows an American cockroach to evade predators? Options: A. Its ability to fly, B. Its ability to swim, C. Its sensory hairs or structures that pick up subtle air currents, D. Its camouflage abilities Correct Option: C
Question 5: What is one of the unique features of a cockroach's digestive system? Options: A. Its ability to digest only plant-based materials, B. Its ability to store nitrogen-containing wastes in its body, C. Its ability to produce digestive enzymes that break down a wide range of organic matter, D. Its ability to absorb nutrients through its skin Correct Option: C
Question 6: What is one of the ways in which cockroaches can recycle nitrogen in their bodies? Options: A. By storing it in their muscles, B. By excreting it as waste, C. By having a resident group of bacteria recycle the nitrogen into useful molecules, D. By absorbing it from the air Correct Option: C
Question 7: What is one of the reasons why cockroaches are able to thrive in environments with low levels of nitrogen? Options: A. Because they are able to absorb nitrogen from the air, B. Because they are able to store nitrogen in their bodies, C. Because they have a unique set of digestive enzymes that allow them to break down nitrogen-poor materials, D. Because they are able to produce their own nitrogen Correct Option: C
Question 8: What is one of the ways in which cockroaches are able to defend themselves against pesticides? Options: A. By producing more detoxification enzymes, B. By having a thicker exoskeleton, C. By being able to fly away quickly, D. By being able to hide in small spaces Correct Option: A
Question 9: What is one of the reasons why German cockroaches are able to evolve resistance to pesticides so quickly? Options: A. Because they are able to adapt to changing environments, B. Because they are able to reproduce quickly, C. Because they are able to communicate with each other, D. Because they are able to absorb nutrients from the air Correct Option: B
Question 10: What is one of the reasons why cockroaches would likely not survive a nuclear apocalypse? Options: A. Because they are able to withstand high levels of radiation, B. Because they are able to fly away quickly, C. Because their habitats and food sources would be severely compromised, D. Because they are able to adapt to changing environments Correct Option: C


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
After analyzing the ground truth MCQ and the generated MCQs, I found that the most similar generated MCQ is not an exact match, but it is related to the physical adaptations of the American cockroach.

The ground truth MCQ asks about the ability of the American cockroach to escape stomping attempts by humans, which can be attributed to its walking or running speed and its flattened and flexible body.

The most similar generated MCQ is Question 4, which asks about one of the physical adaptations that allows an American cockroach to evade predators. The correct option is its sensory hairs or structures that pick up subtle air currents, which is related to its ability to detect and respond to threats.

However, another generated MCQ that is also relevant is Question 3, which asks about the estimated speed of an American cockroach in terms of human equivalent speed. This question is related to the walking or running speed aspect of the ground truth MCQ.

But the most similar generated MCQ that matches the content of the ground truth MCQ is not present. However, if I had to choose one, I would say that Question 4 is the most similar, but it would be more accurate to say that a combination of Question 3 and Question 4 would be the most similar.

So, I will provide the index of Question 4 as the most similar generated MCQ, but with the caveat that it is not an exact match.

Index of the most similar generated MCQ: 4

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 3, Question 3
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
In the Egyptian Book of the Dead,
there’s a banishment spell that declares, “Be far from me, 
O vile cockroach.” More than 3,000 years later, 
we’re still trying to oust these insects. But from poison traps 
to hastily brandished slippers, cockroaches seem to weather 
just about everything we throw at them. So what makes cockroaches so hard to kill? There are nearly 5,000 cockroach species. 99% of them live in a range of habitats
where they play important ecological roles by recycling dead or decaying 
organic matter and nourishing other animals. But a couple dozen species adapted to live
in close association with humans. German and American cockroaches
are among the most common. And they owe their resilience
to a combination of physical and chemical adaptations. When it comes to old-fashioned 
removal methods, they're troublingly tenacious. An American cockroach’s sensory hairs 
or structures pick up subtle air currents and rapidly send signals 
to its central nervous system. The roach can then turn and sprint
away within a few milliseconds. And it’s among the fastest invertebrates
ever recorded, reaching speeds of up to 50
body lengths per second. This would be the human equivalent of
running more than 300 kilometers per hour. And finding a hiding place is no problem. With its flattened, flexible body, an American cockroach can squeeze into 
spaces less than a quarter of its height. Even if we do land a hit, 
it can withstand compressive forces of up to 900 times its own weight 
by distributing the impact along its body. And the cockroach’s toughness
doesn’t end there. Cockroaches can eat a variety 
of organic matter, including hair, dead skin, 
adhesives, and paper. This is made possible by an expansive set 
of digestive enzymes. Cockroaches are able to thrive 
even in nutrient-poor environments. Roaches often eat decaying foods
that are low in nitrogen— an essential component
of DNA and proteins. But they survive by storing 
nitrogen-containing wastes in their bodies and having a resident group
of bacteria recycle the nitrogen into useful molecules for them. Meanwhile, German cockroaches
will eat their own poop, vomit, and dead or dying colony members 
without hesitation. An American cockroach will
frolic in sewers, consuming excrement and toting microbes
like Staphylococcus aureus and E.coli. But they’ll rarely suffer
any consequences. This is because they’re equipped 
with genes that provide immunity against numerous pathogens. These genes are often duplicated 
many times over. So when infected, the cockroach’s 
immune system efficiently unleashes many antimicrobial molecules. Cockroaches also have a slew of defenses
against pesticides. When a non-resistant roach walks 
on a surface that’s been sprayed with a pyrethroid insecticide, 
for example, the results will likely be fatal. Once absorbed, the chemical binds
to sodium channel proteins, which help propagate nerve impulses. The pyrethroid keeps 
the sodium channels open, so the nerves fire repeatedly. And soon, the cockroach dies. But if a resistant roach is exposed 
to pyrethroids, it’ll be just fine. Genetic mutations have given
them sodium channels that the pyrethroids can’t bind to. The cockroach also produces more
detoxification enzymes, which render the pesticide harmless, and the cockroach simply excretes 
it as a waste. Because German cockroaches
reproduce especially quickly, populations may evolve resistance 
to a new pesticide within months. So far, they're already resistant
to 43 different chemicals. But contrary to popular belief, cockroaches would probably not survive 
a nuclear apocalypse. Compared with other insects, cockroaches are only mildly
tolerant to radiation. They would die near the sites
of nuclear explosions and would still be severely
compromised miles away. Moreover, disasters that threaten humanity also jeopardize the habitats and buffets 
we provide roaches. Perhaps the only way to beat them 
is through our mutual destruction. Or maybe cockroaches would find 
even more surprising ways to thrive long after we’re gone.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 3, Question 4
